The marble tomb, the proudly sculptur'd bust,</br>The vain may prize, to make their mem'ry live;</br>But can these keepers frail retain their trust?</br>Time mingles all, unconscious of reprieve.

In vain th' impassion'd verse shall tell their fate,</br>All varnish'd o'er, to cheat admiring eyes;</br>But scann'd by truth, their gaudiest colours fail,</br>And but to fade their greenest laurels rise.
Not so who look beyond this earthly sphere,</br>Their paths more brighten'd by the heavenly light,</br>Who sees no recompense from honors here,</br>Nor by dissentions human praise invite.
What tho' their truth held on its humble way,</br>Along the peaceful calm serene of life,</br>Their virtues never blaz'd upon the day,</br>In ostentation with the sons of strife.
Tho' unadorn'd their truth in simple plight,</br>Nor like a harlot us'd a false disguise,</br>Redd'ning a wrathful meteor on the sight,</br>Nor borrow'd trappings from the worldly wise.
Still should their loss impel a generous tear,</br>If ever Gratitude its debt confess'd,</br>Or ever virtue earn'd a tribute dear,</br>Or ever justice warm'd the human breast.
CORBYN, departed from this world of woe,</br>Might well demand the panegyric lay;</br>Might well compel the feeling source to flow,</br>Or plead example for the warmest praise.
Not so he wish'd — but as some modest flower,</br>Breathes its sweet fragrance on some lonely soil,</br>He sav'd the wretched from affliction's power,</br>And eas'd the yoke of misery and toil.
As Enoch walking, it sufficed to know,</br>They felt the good, for whom it was design'd;</br>In blessing blest, the high extatic glow,</br>Leaves lesser praises, for each lesser mind.
Those feel that peace the world cannot give,</br>And give as freely as to them a given;</br>They hear that voice the world will not receive,</br>The songs of triumph, and the harps of heaven.
Pure source of love, and principle of truth,</br>In every bosom still thyself reveal;</br>Still bear thy witness in our rising youth,</br>Still let the aged all thy influence feel.
This vital spirit shall declare its source,</br>From everlasting yields to no decline;</br>This, like the eagle, shall renew its force,</br>Its end perfection, and its aim divine.</br>
